sub_topic: Finding the chromatic polynomial of a graph.
message_1: Consider an undirected graph G with 5 vertices and the following edges: AB, BC, CD, DE, and EA. Determine the chromatic polynomial of the graph G.
message_2:
The chromatic polynomial of a graph G, denoted as P(G, k), is a polynomial that counts the number of proper k-colorings of the graph. A proper k-coloring is an assignment of k colors to the vertices of the graph such that no two adjacent vertices have the same color.

The given graph G is a cycle of length 5, which we can denote as C5. To find the chromatic polynomial of C5, we can use the recursive formula for the chromatic polynomial of a cycle:

P(Cn, k) = (k-1)^n + (-1)^n (k-1)

In our case, n = 5. Plugging this into the formula, we get:

P(C5, k) = (k-1)^5 + (-1)^5 (k-1)

Simplifying, we get:

P(C5, k) = (k-1)^5 - (k-1)

This is the chromatic polynomial of the given graph G.
